django.utils.dateformat

PHP date() style date formatting See https://www.php.net/date for format strings

Usage: >>> from datetime import datetime >>> d = datetime.now() >>> df = DateFormat(d) >>> print(df.format(‘jS F Y H:i’)) 7th October 2003 11:39 >>>

class django.utils.dateformat.TimeFormat(obj)[source]

Bases: Formatter

data[source]
timezone = None[source]
a()[source]

‘a.m.’ or ‘p.m.’

A()[source]

‘AM’ or ‘PM’

e()[source]

Timezone name.

If timezone information is not available, return an empty string.

f()[source]

Time, in 12-hour hours and minutes, with minutes left off if they’re zero. Examples: ‘1’, ‘1:30’, ‘2:05’, ‘2’ Proprietary extension.

g()[source]

Hour, 12-hour format without leading zeros; i.e. ‘1’ to ‘12’

G()[source]

Hour, 24-hour format without leading zeros; i.e. ‘0’ to ‘23’

h()[source]

Hour, 12-hour format; i.e. ‘01’ to ‘12’

H()[source]

Hour, 24-hour format; i.e. ‘00’ to ‘23’

i()[source]

Minutes; i.e. ‘00’ to ‘59’

O()[source]

Difference to Greenwich time in hours; e.g. ‘+0200’, ‘-0430’.

If timezone information is not available, return an empty string.

P()[source]

Time, in 12-hour hours, minutes and ‘a.m.’/’p.m.’, with minutes left off if they’re zero and the strings ‘midnight’ and ‘noon’ if appropriate. Examples: ‘1 a.m.’, ‘1:30 p.m.’, ‘midnight’, ‘noon’, ‘12:30 p.m.’ Proprietary extension.

s()[source]

Seconds; i.e. ‘00’ to ‘59’

T()[source]

Time zone of this machine; e.g. ‘EST’ or ‘MDT’.

If timezone information is not available, return an empty string.

u()[source]

Microseconds; i.e. ‘000000’ to ‘999999’

Z()[source]

Time zone offset in seconds (i.e. ‘-43200’ to ‘43200’). The offset for timezones west of UTC is always negative, and for those east of UTC is always positive.

If timezone information is not available, return an empty string.

Bases: TimeFormat

b()[source]

Month, textual, 3 letters, lowercase; e.g. ‘jan’

c()[source]

ISO 8601 Format Example : ‘2008-01-02T10:30:00.000123’

d()[source]

Day of the month, 2 digits with leading zeros; i.e. ‘01’ to ‘31’

D()[source]

Day of the week, textual, 3 letters; e.g. ‘Fri’

E()[source]

Alternative month names as required by some locales. Proprietary extension.

F()[source]

Month, textual, long; e.g. ‘January’

I()[source]

‘1’ if daylight saving time, ‘0’ otherwise.

j()[source]

Day of the month without leading zeros; i.e. ‘1’ to ‘31’

l()[source]

Day of the week, textual, long; e.g. ‘Friday’

L()[source]

Boolean for whether it is a leap year; i.e. True or False

m()[source]

Month; i.e. ‘01’ to ‘12’

M()[source]

Month, textual, 3 letters; e.g. ‘Jan’

n()[source]

Month without leading zeros; i.e. ‘1’ to ‘12’

N()[source]

Month abbreviation in Associated Press style. Proprietary extension.

o()[source]

ISO 8601 year number matching the ISO week number (W)

r()[source]

RFC 5322 formatted date; e.g. ‘Thu, 21 Dec 2000 16:01:07 +0200’

S()[source]

English ordinal suffix for the day of the month, 2 characters; i.e. ‘st’, ‘nd’, ‘rd’ or ‘th’.

t()[source]

Number of days in the given month; i.e. ‘28’ to ‘31’

U()[source]

Seconds since the Unix epoch (January 1 1970 00:00:00 GMT)

w()[source]

Day of the week, numeric, i.e. ‘0’ (Sunday) to ‘6’ (Saturday)

W()[source]

ISO-8601 week number of year, weeks starting on Monday

y()[source]

Year, 2 digits with leading zeros; e.g. ‘99’.

Y()[source]

Year, 4 digits with leading zeros; e.g. ‘1999’.

z()[source]

Day of the year, i.e. 1 to 366.
